events.originalText: Jared Lee Loughner opened fire at a public meeting held by U.S. representative Gabby Giffords in Tucson, Arizona, killing six people and injuring twelve others.
events.subtitle: Jared Lee Loughner
events.headline: Jared Lee Loughner opens fire in Tucson, Arizona, killing six

events.originalText: Gunmen from an offshoot of the Front for the Liberation of the Enclave of Cabinda attacked the bus transporting the Togo national football team to the Africa Cup of Nations in Angola, killing three people.
events.subtitle: Front for the Liberation of the Enclave of Cabinda
events.headline: Gunmen attack Togo national football team in Angola, killing three

events.originalText: Jeremy Wade Delle committed suicide in his high-school class in Richardson, Texas, an event that inspired the Pearl Jam song "Jeremy".
events.subtitle: Richardson, Texas
events.headline: Jeremy Wade Delle commits suicide in Richardson, Texas

events.originalText: In Trans-en-Provence, France, a local farmer reported a UFO sighting claimed to be "perhaps the most completely and carefully documented sighting of all time".
events.subtitle: Trans-en-Provence
events.headline: UFO sighting reported in Trans-en-Provence, France

events.originalText: Three bombs attributed to Armenian nationalists exploded across Moscow, killing seven people and injuring 37 people.
events.subtitle: 1977 Moscow bombings
events.headline: Armenian nationalists' bombs kill seven in Moscow

events.originalText: Following Pakistan's defeat in the Bangladesh Liberation War, President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto released Bangladeshi politician Sheikh Mujibur Rahman (pictured) from prison in response to international pressure.
events.subtitle: Pakistani Instrument of Surrender
events.headline: President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto releases Sheikh Mujibur Rahman from prison

events.originalText: Five Evangelical Christian missionaries from the United States were killed by the Huaorani in the rainforest of Ecuador shortly after making contact with them.
events.subtitle: Evangelicalism
events.headline: Huaorani kill five U.S. missionaries in Ecuador

events.originalText: Reza Shah issued the Kashf-e hijab decree, ordering Iranian police to remove hijabs from any women in public.
events.subtitle: Reza Shah
events.headline: Reza Shah orders removal of hijabs in public in Iran

events.originalText: U.S. president Woodrow Wilson announced his Fourteen Points for a moral cause and for post–World War I peace in Europe.
events.subtitle: Woodrow Wilson
events.headline: Woodrow Wilson announces Fourteen Points for post-World War I peace

events.originalText: Blackstone Library (pictured), the first branch of the Chicago Public Library system, was dedicated.
events.subtitle: Blackstone Library
events.headline: Blackstone Library dedicated in Chicago

events.originalText: American statistician Herman Hollerith received a patent for his electromechanical tabulating machine for punched-card data.
events.subtitle: Herman Hollerith
events.headline: Herman Hollerith patents tabulating machine for punched-card data

events.originalText: George Washington delivered the first State of the Union address in New York City, then the provisional capital of the United States.
events.subtitle: George Washington
events.headline: George Washington delivers first State of the Union address in New York City

events.originalText: George Frideric Handel's opera Ariodante premiered at the Covent Garden Theatre in London.
events.subtitle: George Frideric Handel
events.headline: George Frideric Handel's opera Ariodante premieres in London

events.originalText: Scottish student Thomas Aikenhead became the last person in Great Britain to be executed for blasphemy.
events.subtitle: Thomas Aikenhead
events.headline: Thomas Aikenhead executed for blasphemy in Great Britain

events.originalText: Lotario dei Conti was elected as Pope Innocent III; he later worked to restore papal power in Rome.
events.subtitle: 1198 papal election
events.headline: Lotario dei Conti elected as Pope Innocent III
